pullRequest.body:
Prove `DihedralGroup.r_one_zpow`, which extends `r_one_pow` to the integers.

---

@ocfnash hoping you can help - I've opened my PR here, but it doesn't seem to be appearing in the review queue

bors d=@erdOne

Thanks!

:v: erdOne can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

```suggestion
  cases k <;> simp [r_inv]
```
nice 😅

This should probably be called `inv_r` instead because despite the notation it is `inv (r i)`.

And can you also add `inv_sr` and `r_zero` and make them simp?
done
Sorry, I meant `r 0 = 1`.

Should `r 0` really simplify to `1`? I had a proof that looks something like this where I want to rewrite it the other way

```
example (h : (r (i : ZMod n)) = 1) : i = 0 := by
  have : 1 = r (0 : ZMod n) := by rfl
  rw [this] at h
  simp at h
  exact h
```
I also realised that the equality `r 0 = 1` is already stated as `one_def`
I'll also delete the equality `(r i) ^ 0 = r 0` as I've never needed it
Of course you could and might want to rewrite `1` with `r 0` in proofs, but `1` is simpler than `r 0` so the simplifier should still fire on it.

My point is more that I was using the `simp` tactic as a "normal form rewriting" tactic (rewrite all terms of type `DihedralGroup` to either `r <something>` or `sr <something>`), but I do see that normal forms can be quite complicated in general and it might not be a good idea to use `simp` for this purpose
Adding `r 0 = 1` as a simp theorem seems to mess up the proof in `OddCommuteEquiv` in a way that I don't know how to fix
I think this should be simp as well.
Thinking about this a bit more, I think it is better to provide `r i ^ k = r (k * i)` as a simp lemma.
I think that can be left for future work, and in that future PR the `pow` and `zpow` lemmas can be adjusted at the same time.

a little cleaner:
```suggestion
@[simp]
theorem inv_r (i : ZMod n) : (r i)⁻¹ = r (-i) :=
  rfl

@[simp]
theorem inv_sr (i : ZMod n) : (sr i)⁻¹ = sr i :=
  rfl
```

pullRequest.title: feat: Prove `r_one_zpow`
